message.content: We refer to the website of Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) for help. As of 2017, the current ACGME standards limit continuous duty hours for first-year residents to a maximum of 24 hours, with an additional 4 hours allowed for appropriate transitions of care. The duty hour during which the resident received the patient violated this standard, as the resident had already been on duty for 27 hours. All other options were within the maximum limits set by the ACGME.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most recent ACGME standards limit residents to a maximum of 24 consecutive hours of duty with additional time for necessary transitions and providing care for stable patients. Therefore, the duty hour during which this resident received the patient, which was at the 27th hour of continuous duty, is in violation of the standards. The maximum number of hours per week (80), minimum rest hours between duty periods (10), and maximum number of hours for continued patient care (4) are all in compliance with the standards.

We refer to the ACGME website for help. The ACGME has established duty hour limits for first-year residents to a maximum of 16 hours per shift, with an additional 4 hours for appropriate transition of care. The resident in this scenario received the patient at the 27th hour of continuous duty, violating this requirement. The maximum number of hours per week and the minimum rest hours between duty periods are also regulated by the ACGME but are not violated in this scenario. The maximum number of hours for continued patient care is not specified by the ACGME.

We refer to the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) website for help. As of 2011, the ACGME restricted continuous duty time to 16 hours for first-year residents and 24 hours for residents in their second year of training or beyond. Therefore, the violation in this case is the duty hour during which the resident received the patient, which was at the 27th hour of his continuous duty. All other options are within the ACGME standards.

We refer to the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) website. According to the most recent ACGME standards, residents must not work for more than 24 consecutive hours with additional time for necessary activities such as providing effective transitions of care. Therefore, the resident’s duty hour during which he received the patient for over 27 hours is in violation of the most recent ACGME standards. The maximum number of hours per week this resident was on duty is also in violation (must not exceed 80 hours per week averaged over 4 weeks), as well as the maximum number of hours allowed for continued patient care (must not exceed 24 hours) and the minimum rest hours this resident had between duty periods (must have at least 10 hours).

We refer to the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) standards. As of 2017, the standards state that residents must not work more than 24-hour shifts, with up to 4 additional hours allowed for activities related to patient safety (such as handovers and transitions), and must have a minimum of 10 hours off-duty between shifts. Therefore, the duty hour during which the resident received the patient (27th hour of continuous duty) violates the current ACGME standards. The maximum number of hours per week (76) and the maximum number of hours allowed for continued patient care (up to 30 hours on the same shift) are also above the current ACGME standards. However, the minimum rest hours this resident had between duty periods (12 hours) meets the current ACGME standards.

We refer to ACGME website for help. As of July 2021, the current ACGME duty hour standards include an 80-hour per week limit averaged over a four-week period, a maximum shift length of 24 hours, and mandatory rest periods between shifts. However, the resident in this scenario received the patient at the 27th hour of his continuous duty, which violates the maximum shift length and minimum rest hours standards. Therefore, the correct answer is (A).

We refer to the ACGME website for help. The most recent standards state that interns (first-year residents) and residents must not be scheduled for more than 24 consecutive hours of duty. Therefore, the duty hour during which this resident received the patient (27th hour) violated the standards. The maximum number of hours per week (80 hours, averaged over 4 weeks), minimum rest hours (at least 8 hours between duty periods, with some exceptions), and maximum number of hours allowed for continued patient care (up to 4 additional hours for continuity of care and education on rare occasions) are all in compliance with the current ACGME standards.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most recent standards set by ACGME forbid residents from beginning new duty hours after being on duty for 24 consecutive hours. In this case, the resident received the patient at the 27th hour of his continuous duty, which violates this standard. The other options are not in violation of the most recent standards set by ACGME.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The most recent standards set by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) limit continuous duty to a maximum of 24 hours, which means that the duty hour during which this resident received the patient (27th hour) is in violation of these standards. The maximum number of hours per week this resident was on duty (76 hours), the minimum rest hours this resident had between duty periods (12 hours), and the maximum number of hours allowed for continued patient care (30 hours) are all within the current ACGME standards.
